newsitem.title: UK: Traders ponder fate of final Iraqi crude cargoes.
newsitem.headline: Traders ponder fate of final Iraqi crude cargoes.

text.p: No liftings of Iraqi Kirkuk crude have been set for the final two weeks of the first 180-day period of the U.N. oil-for-food exchange, indicating Baghdad is close to its $2 billion revenue target under the scheme, traders said on Tuesday.
And if crude prices remain firm cargoes could be at risk of deferral or cancellation if the scheme's revenues are judged by U.N. overseers to have overshot the target.
The final loading on May 25 of a one million barrel cargo at the Turkish port of Ceyhan is a full two weeks ahead of the expiry of the six-month scheme on June 7, they said.
Some traders said there was doubt about whether the loading, planned by Trafigura under a term contract with Iraq's State Oil Marketing Organisation (SOMO), would be given final U.N. approval.
In addition, there was uncertainty over the fate of two cargo of Iraq's Basrah light due to load from the Gulf port of Mina al-Bakr in the final two weeks of the programme.
"The last cargoes to be scheduled are definitely at risk," a Mediterranean crude trader said.
"It's a complete reversal of the situation in the first quarter of the programme when they had to increase loadings in a falling market."

Lifters said U.N. overseers were taking "quite a time" to approve liftings, in marked contrast to the early months of the programme when approval would be given by the overseers within two days of application.
"The problem is to get U.N. approval. Then you are safe," one European lifter said.

"Remember that under this scheme a loading programme is just a schedule. It's not binding. It doesn't mean you have final approval. You can have SOMO approval but without the U.N. approval it won't happen.
"I'm sure the U.N. operates within a safety net. That is to say that the U.N. only approves a lifting when they are sure it will not violate the revenue limit."
Iraq's agreement with the U.N., which began on December 10, allows Baghdad to sell $2 billion over the six months and must be reviewed for possible renewal by the Security Council before it expires.
Receipt limits are actually pegged at $2.14 billion over the six months to June 7, allowing an extra $140 million to pay Turkey pipeline fees.
Nearly two-thirds of oil proceeds are earmarked for food and medicine purchases, as part of a humanitarian exception to sanctions placed on Iraq after it invaded Kuwait in 1990.

Before June 7, U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan is to issue a report on the accord's effectiveness in alleviating suffering in the country, within a broad progress report on the deal's implementation.
The U.N. Security Council was then to take action on renewing the accord.

The programme has been bedevilled by its value-based structure. This has ensured that in a falling international oil market Iraqi must increase exports to meet the target and thereby accelerate the losses. In a rising market, it must curb exports thus helping lift oil market values.

One lifter was resigned to the continuance of the structure. "I don't really know if the structure of the deal will change in the second period. Yes, it means a lot of time and effort and uncertainty getting approvals, but no one ever said this was going to be easy."
Traders say Total, which has a cargo loading on Tuesday at Ceyhan, had to wait 10 days for the May 9 approval from the overseers for a 360,000 barrel top-up.
SOMO has not signed any new contract since the end of April.

Another Mediterranean trader said he felt the Trafigura cargo would be loaded but he added there was "complete uncertainty" about how the revenue would be accounted -- possibly, but not inevitably, on the books of a second 180-day programme.
Trafigura, a trading company, is understood already to have committed the cargo to a refinery buyer.
Traders have said Kirkuk exports in May are expected to rise slightly to around 445,000 barrels per day (bpd) from an original 430,000 bpd programme for April.
Full Iraqi exports under the oil sale, including sales of Basrah Light from Iraq's Gulf terminal at Mina al-Bakr, have been running at around 750,000 bpd in recent weeks.
-- London newsroom +44 171 542 7646
